title: Nonlinear statistics of quantum transport in chaotic cavities

title_detail.value: Nonlinear statistics of quantum transport in chaotic cavities

summary:
In the framework of the random matrix approach, we apply the theory of
Selberg's integral to problems of quantum transport in chaotic cavities. All
the moments of transmission eigenvalues are calculated analytically up to the
fourth order. As a result, we derive exact explicit expressions for the
skewness and kurtosis of the conductance and transmitted charge as well as for
the variance of the shot-noise power in chaotic cavities. The obtained results
are generally valid at arbitrary numbers of propagating channels in the two
attached leads. In the particular limit of large (and equal) channel numbers,
the shot-noise variance attends the universal value 1/(64\beta) that determines
a universal Gaussian statistics of shot-noise fluctuations in this case.

In the framework of the random matrix approach, we apply the theory of Selberg's integral to problems of
quantum transport in chaotic cavities. All the moments of transmission eigenvalues are calculated analytically
up to the fourth order. As a result, we derive exact explicit expressions for the skewness and kurtosis of the
conductance and transmitted charge as well as for the variance of the shot-noise power in chaotic cavities. The
obtained results are generally valid at arbitrary numbers of propagating channels in the two attached leads. In
the particular limit of large (and equal) channel numbers, the shot-noise variance attends the universal value
1/64β that determines a universal Gaussian statistics of shot-noise fluctuations in this case.
PACS numbers: 73.23.-b, 73.50.Td, 05.45.Mt, 73.63.Kv

Covariance of g and p.– It is also instructive to consider
statistical correlations between the conductance and the shotnoise power that can be characterized by their covariance
cov(g, p) = hgpi − hgihpi. This quantity involves moments
of Ti 's up to the third order. Surprisingly, the resulting exact
formula for cov(g, p)/var(g) turns out to be given precisely
by the r.h.s. of Eq. (6). This expression vanishes in symmetric cavities at β = 2 that can be easily seen again as a consequence of the symmetry of the distributions. In this case,
therefore, g and p become uncorrelated on the level of their
averages and it would be interesting to understand to which
extent this holds for their higher moments in general.

Discussion.– We have applied essentially the theory of Selberg's integral to problems of quantum transport in chaotic
cavities. The cumulants up to the fourth order for current
and conductance fluctuations and up to the second order for
shot-noise have been calculated exactly at arbitrary channel
numbers and symmetry parameter β. We note that the proposed method can be also used for determining the corresponding distributions in closed form suitable for an analytic
work in the case of a few open channels as well as for numerical implementations.7,20 Our analysis of shot-noise statistics suggests that in close analogy with universal conductance
fluctuations,19 we may characterize universal fluctuations of
shot-noise by their cumulants as follows

relevant experimental data. For example, measurements of
up to the fifth cumulants of the transmitted charge have been
recently done in a weakly coupled quantum dot.23 However,
performing similar experiments for a lower impedance device,
such as a perfectly open chaotic cavity with several modes in
the leads, requires a much higher detector resolution that represents a current experimental challenge. On the other hand,
the conductance distribution in chaotic cavities24 has been
also tested by means of experiments with microwaves.25 A
direct comparison with our results in this case could be, however, not so straightforward, as it involves taking into account
effects of dephasing and absorption24,26 as well.
As another potential application of our results, we mention quantized transport in graphene p-n junctions that
has been very recently studied both experimentally27 and
theoretically.28 The exact RMT results for higher cumulants
of the conductance and noise may be useful for understanding possible mechanisms of edge mode mixing in the bipolar
regime leading to chaotic transport there.28 Further work in
this and in the other directions mentioned above is needed.
